case_data.name: EEOC v. WHOLESALE ELECTRIC SUPPLY COMPANY OF HOUSTON
case_data.plaintiff_description: Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, on behalf of one or more workers.
settlement_agreement: Court Approved Settlement or Consent Decree
case_data.summary:
In September 2002, the Houston office of the EEOC brought this Title VII and ADEA suit against Wholesale Electric Supply Company of Houston in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Texas. The complaint alleged that the defendant discriminated against the claimants by failing to promote them and discharging them because of their sex (female) and ages (62 and 54). The case settled by entry of a consent decree in January 2004.

The two year consent decree required the defendant to refrain from discrimination and retaliation, provide the claimants with neutral references, expunge the claimant's records, provide EEO training for its managers, and pay the claimants $55,000.

documents.title: Consent Decree
documents.text:
IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
FOR THE SOUTHERN DISTRICT OF TEXAS 
HOUSTON DIVISION 
EQUAL EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITY  § 
COMMISSION,  § 
§ 
Plaintiff,  § 
§  CIVIL ACTION NO. H-02-3668 
v.  § 
§ 
vv.HOLESALEELECTRICSUPPLY  § 
COMPANY OF HOUSTON, L.P.  § 
§ 
and  § 
§ 
WHOLESALE ELECTRIC SUPPLY  § 
COMP ANY OF HOUSTON, INC.  § 
§ 
Defendants.  § 
-----------------------------§ 
CONSENT DECREE 
The Plaintiff, Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (the "Commission"), alleges in 
this suit that on or about August 1999, Defendant Wholesale Electric Supply Company of Houston, 
L.P. ("Defendant")  failed to promote Clara Williams to a sales manager job because of her sex and 
I, 
age, then 63; and that on or about July 16,2001, Defendant laid off Clara Williams and Cynthia 
Bedard because of their sex and ages, then 64 and 52, respectively in violation of Title VII of the 
Civil Rights Act of 1964, as amended, by Title I of the Civil Rights Act of 1991, and the Age 
Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967, as amended, 29 U.S.C. §621 et seq. ("ADEA") 
Defendant answered the Complaint, and denied liability and specifically denied engaging in 
1  The other entity named herein, Wholesale Electric Supply Company of Houston, Inc., no longer 
exists.  As set forth in the Complaint at paragraph 5, in or about November of 1999, Wholesale 
Electric Supply Company of Houston, Inc. changed its name to and/or became Wholesale Electric 
Supply Company of Houston, L.P. 

any discriminatory employment practices. Neither this Consent Decree nor the furnishing of any 
payment to any individual claimant by the terms of this Consent Decree shall be construed as an 
admission by Defendant of any liability of unlawful conduct. To the contrary, Defendant denies that 
it is any way liable to the EEOC or any individual claimant. 
In the interests of resolving this matter, to avoid the costs of litigation, and as a result of 
having engaged in extensive negotiations, the parties have agreed that this action should be finally 
resolved by entry of this Consent Decree. 
The parties stipulate to the jurisdiction of the Court and waive a hearing and the entry of 
findings of fact and conclusions of law. 
IT IS THEREFORE ORDERED: 
1.  This Consent Decree is entered in full and complete settlement of any and all claims 
arising out of or contained in EEOC Charge Nos. 330-AO-2071 and EEOC Charge No. 330-A1-
2665), and Civil Action No. H-02-3668. The Consent Decree constitutes a complete resolution of 
all claims that were made by the Commission against Defendant in this action. This Consent Decree 
constitutes the complete and exclusive agreement between the Parties with respect to the matters 
referred to herein. No representation or inducement to compromise this action have been made, other 
than those recited or referenced in this Consent Decree. No waiver, modification or amendment of 
any provision of this Consent Decree shall be effective unless made in writing, approved by the 
Parties to this Consent Decree and approved or ordered by the Court. 
2.  Defendant agrees that it will not discriminate against any employee or applicant for 
employment because of his or her sex or age in violation ofT  itle VII or the ADEA. Defendant agrees 
to hire applicants based on the best qualifications available and not on account of any discriminatory 
factors. 
2 

3.  Defendant agrees that it will not discriminate or retaliate in any manner against any 
individual because he or she has made a charge, testified, assisted, or participated in any manner in 
the investigation by the Commission or court proceeding in connection with this case. 
4.  Defendant agrees to pay Clara Williams $40,000.  Defendant agrees to pay Cynthia 
Bedard $15,000. These payments, less all applicable required withholdings under federal and state 
laws,  will be made within fourteen  (14)  days  from  the entry of this Consent Decree or the 
individual's execution and delivery to Defendant of a standard release of claims, whichever is later. 
Copies of the check will be mailed to the EEOC within fourteen (14) days from the entry of this 
Consent Decree or the individuals' standard release of claims, whichever is later at the following 
address: Rudy L. Sustaita, EEOC Houston District Office,  Floor, Houston, Texas 77002. 
7th 
5.  In response to a written request for a reference from a third party about Ms. Williams' 
or Ms. Bedard's employment and! or performance wi th Defendant, Defendant shall provide only their 
dates of employment, last position held and last wage rate. Defendant shall not reference Ms. 
Williams' or Ms. Bedard's charges of discrimination, this lawsuit or this Consent Decree. Should 
either Ms. Williams' or Ms. Bedard's separation be raised by a third party employer, that employer 
shall be instructed that their separations did not reflect negatively on them or their performance. 
6.  Defendant agrees to segregate all documents related to Ms.  Williams' and Ms. 
Bedard's charges of discrimination and the Commission's lawsuit in separate confidential folders. 
These documents shall not be a part of either Ms. Williams' or Ms. Bedard's personnel files. 
7.  Defendant agrees to provide Equal Employment Opportunity (HEEO") training to its 
managers in its Clute, Texas locations regarding employment discrimination, including, but not 
limited to the illegality of gender-based and age-based employment decisions. The training shall be 
conducted within 6 months of the entry of this Decree. Defendant shall notify the EEOC of the 
3 

training by indicating when and where the training took place and by identifying the trainers and the 
attendees. The notification or report shall be submitted to the EEOC at the following address: Rudy 
L. Sustaita, EEOC Houston District Office, 7th Floor, Houston, Texas 77002. 
8.  Defendant agrees to post, in a public area of its facility in Clute Texas, a notice of 
nondiscrimination. The notice is attached as Exhibit "A." 
9.  The EEOC,and Defendant shall bear their own costs and attorney's fees. 
10.  This Consent Decree shall remain in effect for two years from its entry. 
Signed on this  l?-fh  day of "J""AVvA If Y 2004 at Houston, Texas. 
Si ..' L'_~ 
United States District Judge 
4
